If anything her video is more of a commentary on the limits of language and how it does not always reflect what we are trying to convey.

For example the sentence ‚ÄúAmber is smart‚Äù is by default typically judged as laudatory, but maybe I‚Äòm using it to imply that Amber is a bad person, willing to use her wit in order to swindle others. If I use the word ‚Äúguys‚Äù with no malevolent intent, there is no reason to be offended.

What I want to know is the etymology of a word.  So, that is what I set out to do.  The term "guy" or "guys", in its genesis, has nothing to do with gender.  It comes from Dutch and German words meaning "ropes".  It is nautical in nature.  While "guy lines" in English are usually in reference to tents and whatnot, the origination had to with boats.  

So, when we say "Hey Guys!"  We could also be saying, "Hey ropes!"  Or, "Hey braided pieces of hemp!"  


And perhaps that is a bit masculine, because very few women at the time were sailors, but so what?  Faggot is a term for a bundle of wood, but also refers to ONLY gay men.  We never call Lesbians faggot.  If faggot and guy are related to men it is only because men have largely been rulers and many, if not most derogatory slang will be directed towards a ruling class.  In this case, the ruling class has been mostly male.  So "Guys" became a male term, even though it simply meant "ropes".
Sydney, Sydney, Sydney.  I think you missed the most important gender neutral term that we should all start using immediately: Comrades.

Yea, I get their point and don't think they are wrong about it. But the person saying something is not the only member of the communication - as much as we are responsible for what we say, we are also responsible for how we interpret what we hear. And when somebody chooses to be offended by a word that was clearly not said with any sort of ill intent, that is on them.

I'd also point out that in our modern society, that accepts all and any gender-identities no matter what kind of complex mix of biology and psychology they are, gender-defining words don't have much meaning anymore anyway. So rather than monitoring which of these words we say in which situation, I think it would make more sense to simply redefine all of them to mean "person".

commentThread.commentText: wtf is a cisgender?

The idea of a male term being used to address a group of "carbon-based life forms of the homo-sapien species" actually has been around in language for centuries - if not, millennia. 

I took 5 years of Latin, and one of the first grammar rules I learned was about gender. You wanna know how it works? You refer to women as feminine nouns, males as masculine nouns, and groups of both as neuter nou..OH WAIT, you actually refer to groups of mixed genders as masculine. I'm not sure that this is in and of itself inherently sexist at all. In fact, I believe it's an exaggeration and over analyzation. At the end of the day, what makes your best friend your bestie? Is it the fact that he or she doesn't offend you? Or rather, is it the fact that he or she has your best intentions in mind regardless of any accidentally offensive things they may say. 

Two things to note off of that: 

First, language is simply a verbal expression of our own feelings, which means it is A) highly subjective and B) highly interpretable. The language context is exemplified by tone, body language, and attitude. Second, in human interactions, trusting the other's intentions and heart is key to growing any relationship. If you're offended by the words a person chose without realizing that they meant absolutely no harm and was just trying to verbalize feelings (and may have made a mistake, we're all human....or are we?? jk). You might as well get offended because someone wrote your name with a heart on the sand..because sand is coarse and rough..and gets everywhere - all the while ignoring that it's a heart and the intentions are pure. 

Anyways, that's my 2 cents..err, 2 dollars

Another good (failed) example of doing this is using "herstory" in place of "history" ‚Äî a word that has absolutely nothing to do with gender. Message to the language police: most English words have roots in other languages, or are sometimes even directly borrowed from another language. A word you think is gender-based (other than obvious gender pronouns) almost certainly isn't. I guess I'm learning that language is all about perception and less about intent. And, as a consequence, I have been offending women (some women) all of my life. Being 3/4 of a century old, my formative years were very gender specific (guys were guys and girls were girls) and we didn't mix the terms because it just wasn't accurate to do so. But, as feminism grew in stature among us, we were cautioned that we couldn't use terms like girls, or gals, or ladies because they were offensive. So, what were the approved terms of greeting for women? Nobody really knew and terms like "guys" became quasi-acceptable because we didn't have an alternative word. (Note: Until recently, I didn't know what cisgender referred to. Much to my surprise, I was one.) But, due to my age, I have never referred to a mixed group of men and women as "guys" because, despite dictionary secondary references to "person" , it just doesn't feel right to me. So, if I must greet a mixed group of XX and XY humans, I merely say hello (or some other greeting) and avoid using any colloquial reference to their collective gender identities. This may be more formal, but it works for me.  Keep up the good work. I enjoy your channel.

commentThread.commentText:
Here's an easy one to debunk. The gender wage gap in the Medical Field. And I am sure this applies to 99.999% of all job and career fields out there. For one. The BLS reports that, pay very close attention here, when it comes to "Medical and Health Services Management", that is a mouth full and can be confusing, "Medical and Health Services Management", women make only a mere "77.0% of the 'median' weekly earnings of men". Let's break this down. Shall we? Okay. So. When it comes to the term "Medical and Health Services Management". This includes ALL "MANAGEMENT" keyword. An RN (Registered Nurse) is not typically going to be paid the same as a PhD (Doctorate of Philosophy). A PhD takes anywhere between 4 to even 12 more years of study, and the presentation of your own theory, hypothesis, research, etc. You must put in a lot more money, a lot more time, and a lot more intelligence to get a PhD. A RN on the other hand only requires 4 years of College. This is at the Bachelor's Level. So, the normal time span to get a Bachelor's Degree is 4 years. To get a Master's, the next step up, takes 6 to 8 years. To get a Doctorate or PhD, it can take a total anywhere from 8 to 16 years, or more! It all depends on the person, their intelligence level, how much time they have to put into it versus work time, and financial standing. As of now, roughly 91% of nurses are female. As of now, only roughly 33% of Physicians are female. You see where this is going? (It doesn't take a genius to see this.) If 91% of nurses (which are lower paid, obviously, duh) are female and 33% of Physicians are female, then it comes to say that there will be more females as RN, which are management positions, than Physicians, which are management positions as well. So, therefore, there will be a wage gap in the management department, so to speak. This is a no-brainer. So, what you are telling me, is that by putting forth more time and effort, earning a higher degree and therefore being in a better position to be paid more and be in a more responsible position than that of a female. Having more time lost at work, having earned less and gained more debt along the way. Telling me that I must forego my paycheck that I have earned, to an RN that only spent 4 years, maybe 5, if they are slow for whatever reason, so that the mythical "Gender Wage Gap" can be filled and equalled out. Then, you have lost your mind. Here's an idea for you idiots out there. Grow up, go to school the same amount of time, earn the same level of degrees, earn the same pay. That's it. Not hard. And quit trying to force BS down my throat! Stupid beta lunatics.

@Yara Flahat "Black people taking ownership of it takes the power away, but the second a white person uses that word in regard to a black person - you‚Äôre giving the word it‚Äôs original power back."

You missed my point. You don't take the power back by restricting its use. In restricting its use you're only tacitly admitting the word still holds all the power it once did. When a white person uses the N-word to refer to a black person it is, in large part, the black individual's decision how they interpret that. Words hold no power over us except that which we let them. It is not the white person saying the N-word that gives it its power; it's the people bothered by its use. They are the ones allowing the word to continue to have power over them. If instead the black community repurposed the word and allowed anyone to use it in reference to black people as a way of denoting respect, not disrespect, the very meaning of the word would change and in the process it would be completely robbed of any power it once held. Once it was actually robbed of that power racists would stop using it. They would have to move on to new words, which could be dismantled and repurposed in exactly the same way; effectively robbing racist fucknards of any shred of power they still hold once and for all.

MeatSafeMurderer I see your point, but at the end of the day, how the word should be used and the meaning of it, isn‚Äôt something you or I can dictate. It‚Äôs the black community‚Äôs decision. I‚Äôm not gonna tell them what the right way to use the N word is, and neither should you. Their oppression = their choice how they handle it. 

It leaves a bad taste in my mouth to picture a white person ‚Äúteaching‚Äù the black community about how they should respond to the N word. It‚Äôs up to them. If you want to be an ally, listen to them. If they‚Äôre asking you not to use it, then don‚Äôt use it. It‚Äôs a respect thing.

@Yara Flahat Frankly, I'm not anyone's ally, I don't stand with anyone, I stand on my own, an individual...and I have no wish to be an "ally" if it means that any input I may have, no matter how insightful, is unwelcome or disregarded purely because of the color of my skin. Language is fluid. It changes with the times. The N-word has held its power for far too long...and ultimately vernacular is not really down to the black community; it's down to the majority of the English speaking population in any given country. They can certainly greatly accelerate it in this specific instance...but...even if they collectively decide to fight it do you think the N-word will still mean the same thing in 1,000 years? Maybe. 10,000? Not likely. 100,000? Not fuckin' a chance. Hell, I'd even say it's beginning to lose its meaning and negative connotation already. People use it in the context of friendly banter even now; they just kinda have to tip toe around anyone who isn't in their general friend group.

MeatSafeMurderer You‚Äôre free to do as you please.

All I‚Äôm trying to say is: don‚Äôt be shocked when you don‚Äôt have any black friends, or black people who associate with you find out your viewpoints and get angry at you or call you a racist. You‚Äôre free to do as you want, but you‚Äôre never going to be free from a reaction. I was just advising you on how to live peacefully among black people in your community. But at the end of the day: it is your choice and you reap what you sow.

@Yara Flahat I mean...you do know black people aren't like a homogenous hivemind right? They all have different thoughts and feelings...and they're not all going to react the same way to a what I have to say. Would some be put off knowing me? Sure...but I already know a few who aren't. And to be brutally honest I'm not sure I'd want to be friends with anyone, regardless of skin color, who would outright dismiss what I have to say because I don't happen to have been blessed with black skin...seems kinda...racist...

MeatSafeMurderer I didn‚Äôt say they‚Äôre a hive mind, but there‚Äôs definitely a large disparity between right wing black people and left wing black people (if you look at the data from the last election), so from that you can deduce that the majority of Black Americans identify with left wing politics.

@Yara Flahat Are you inferring my overall political leaning based on an opinion on a single issue, along with everyone who happens to agree on this one singular topic? It seems like a pretty huge assumption...expecially seeing as how I'm not even sure it's partisan. I think people's overall poltical alignment tends to be a little more complex than that; agreeing with the right on some things, the left on others...and who they vote for on any given election cycle will change based on who they think is best representing issues they want addressed in that specific moment. The only people who don't do that are the left / right zealots.

JoDaIs I don‚Äôt identify with right or left wing politics the way America dictates it, you‚Äôre all on crack.

Further, regarding your sense of humor, you just rely on shock factor and stupid edge to try and get a laugh from people as dumb as you. Unfortunately, you‚Äôre all edge and no point. You‚Äôre not even in the realm of funny.

@Yara Flahat         You stated: "You can‚Äôt use generalized statements about slavery being ‚Äúbad to everyone‚Äù to separate white people from this history. It‚Äôs in their ancestral origins..."


Slavery has been an institution used throughout history, not just in the context of the United States. The ancient Romans and Greeks owned slaves, and most of these slaves were probably white. The ancient Egyptians owned slaves. Africans several hundred years ago owned other Africans as slaves.


In human history, it was once common when one group defeated another, to enslave those that lost.


If any human could trace his/her ancestry back far enough, he/she would find both oppressors and the oppressed. White people do not have a monopoly on slavery.

Actually, guys refer to eachother as everything from babies, to kids, to jerks, to arses, to gals/girls/lasses/ladies/etc, to babies/boys/laddies/lads/guys/etc, and OCCASIONALLY as men... the ones who get all riled up don't last long in male circles because it means at least one of, if not most of or all of, the following: 

1. They can't take a joke...
2. They are too serious/stressed...
3. They are too weak/weak-minded/weak willed...
4. They have something bigger going on...
5. They will be the butt-end of most of the jokes...
6. Aren't comfortable with their own sexuality and/or personally identifying traits...
7. Don't get the jokes, think EVERYTHING is literall, etc...
8. They are NOT socially: culpable, fluent, capable, adequate, responsive, experienced, or integrated...

Guys don't necessarily pick on eachother so much as call it like it is, point out thr gaping holes, call out the elephant in the room, challenge eachother to be better (think rivalry...if your rival doesn't have the competitive edge anymore, doesn't have the drive, cannot stand their own shadow, think on their feet, take things in stride, or let things slide [i.e. skill of picking your fights] , then they won't make good rivals to compete against NOR be trustworthy to have your back when sh*t hits the proverbial fan)...

if you can't wear a salmon colored shirt; call eachother by weird names, pronouns, nouns, adjectives & expletives; tell a good joke; take a joke; accept that life isn't perfectly whipped cream and pitless cherries; live life without being perpetually offended: then you will be seen as weak, be treated as such, thr herd will attempt to toughen you up, and upon success accept you back into the herd as "one of the guys"... however, if the herd fails to bring you around because of your character, personality, baggage, and/or innate lack of motivatione, you WILL be culled from the herd... that's how practically ALL tribal/herding mammals operate... it's how the weak fail to propagate their seed, cutting off bad genes... essentially "nipping it at the bud" such that only the stronger, capable, successful, willful, social, and adaptable will make it... the weak are often protected by mammals, especially canines, on journeys, during migrations, etc...but the weak do NOT get some priority for picking their mates...nor do they ger protection when being hunted... they show down the hunters, the fleeing, and the workers, so they become easy targets of outside hunters (this is the case across ALL of the animal kingdom, not just canines or mammals,  let alone just the males )...

In fact, anyone comfortable in their person doesn't get put off by this, whether intentional or not, in jest or malice...

So why is she talking about this in this Vox-ish/HuffPo-is video within a video? * Blares Theme Song from the soundtrack of the movie: 'Inception' * ...i hate this word, but "I'm offended that she's offended that guys aren't offended by being called every name within, in-between, around, and so far out of the book it may very well be in a different library/store... such as gals/girls/ladies/chicas/etc..." ...

And, it seems to me as if, she WOULD be offended if she found out that guys, for the most part, simply just don't care and are NOT offended by such typical speak,  nor are most people, in general, because adults figured out LONG AGO that one must have thicker skin, lest they not make it in society...

And seriously... let's play the logical-start-to-logical-conclusion game... by the rules of ***"Tthe patriarchy"*** :

1. It has been used to keep women in "their place" (their words, not mine, lol)...

2. The patriarchy keeps people from:

However, in Dutch 'traveler'(tr. 'reiziger') is a male gendered noun, and there's a female variant as well(tr. 'reizigster').

Ergo, to include the 0.5%, they literally excluded the 51% of the population, and I'm not even counting the people who aren't travelling but are at stations working or waiting to pick somebody up. All at the cost of 50k euro's to make new recordings, money which could have been better suited to actually run trains on time....

I have to say what words one uses in language does matter. However, one also needs to look at the history of the language and the forms that it is being used in when it is used.
The definition of a word is only a small part, it is the meaning behind the word that is important. The use of 'guys' is an all encompassing unit and not directed towards anyone. Humans are lazy, even in language, we use the shortest and easiest forms that we can. That's why we call all of humanity just 'man'. It is just easier, and we still use it as a non-gender term today as a verb. "Man the units."
The is also "duct tape" vs "duck tape". A language is used to describe something and get the meaning across to another, if that objective is completed that is all that matters. Extra things are tacked on in the form of connotation, but that is only for words that are directed towards a strong meaning; like in the word anorexic which original meant to be skinny or slim but the medical meaning took over and the connotation changed the charge of the word.


What I'm trying to say here is that unless the majority of the English speaking world takes it as a negative connotation or a word that shouldn't be said it is meaningless to try to change it. According to my brief research, the use of 'guy' to mean a person derives from Guy Fawkes Day, predictably enough.

For those not well versed in early modern English history, in 1605 a group of conspirators attempted to blow up Parliament on the day the King was visiting, in what came to be known as the Gunpowder Plot. The most well known of these came to be a man named Guy Fawkes, essentially the explosives expert of the group. 

It later became an English tradition to burn crude wooden 'Guy' effigies on November 5th, and 'guy' came to mean a person of odd or grotesque appearance. 

Not having this tradition in America, 'guy' came to mean a 'fellow' or 'man'.

As Sydney mentions, it started to be used collectively for either sex in the 1930s, which is great, right? They're being inclusive. 

Unless you're someone who wants to rigidly ignore the new meaning a word has developed which includes women and insist it only has its original meaning of simply males, and is thus exclusive.

You don't like this kind of language policing? I got a story for you, then, Sydney. In France, for a while, we had this whole debate about "Inclusive Writing" - Which was basically some academic people trying to hijack portions of our language to change how it works. In english, "They"  is gender neutral. In French, we have a version of "He" and "She" that is plural. He = Il - They (masculine) = Ils / She = Elle - They (Feminine) = Elles - Simple. So, what's the rule when there is both gender in as situation, like: "They are going to a bar" but it's a boy and a girl, here. Well, the masculine plural pronoun will automatically take over. So "Ils vont dans un bar" - Inclusive language, wants to force change the language so that this becomes incorrect and makes it so that the correct way to say it, having both pronouns everytime. So "Il et elle vont dans un bar."

This is a problem for many reasons. First, it's changing years and years of basic phrasing. Second, we live in the era of "gender is whatever the fuck you want it to be", so what happens if we start adopting the new pronouns, too? Now, my simple phrase, becomes a paragraph. Sarcasm aside, my biggest problem is mostly. You know when sometimes, you say something that you've been saying and hearing all your life and someone corrects you like: "Actually, that's grammatically incorrect" ? No? Is it just a French thing? Here is an example: "Au final" - It means "In the end." but it's also completely incorrect. Yet, everyone says it! It's extremely common, to the point where you'll hear in everything from your daily life, to documentaries, movies, music and so on. All though, some persist to correcting people, because technically: "It isn't french." ...

Why am I bringing this up? It's really simple. Like many thing, a language is built and defined by those who uses it, not some kind authority and certainly not the academia, despite how butthurt it can make those people feel. You are no one to try and change how people speak their own language. When you put yourself in a position of authority, kind of like this person did, trying to tell us how we should do our own things, you're guaranteeing only one thing. That thing being a giant middle finger and basically nothing else. You want a more inclusive language? Preaching around isn't the way to do it, just speak it. People around may caught up to it... or you'll quickly realize how hard you made it, by adding unnecessary rules and over complicating your way of speaking. In any case, people hate being preached at and it's fucking astounding that in... urgh... current year, some people STILL don't understand that. It's the perfect way to not get what you want.

So I looked up a few words from that list and hers and found this: Crew (from the mid 15th century) meant a group of soldiers sent as reinforcements.  Folks was a fun one because that's one that she listed.  Folks refers to common people or laity but may have originally come from "host of warriors" and guess what cohorts meant?  Yup, a company of soldiers or band of warriors, specifically one of ten units that makes up a legion.  I don't want to be referred to as part of a team, now.  How offensive!!!  Why?  While it can mean descendent, family, race, as you might guess from those words, it also refers to child-bearing.  Gosh, what am I?  A breeder? Ick.  The origin of the word camper is from the 1630's, and referred to soldiers.  Hmmm, gosh, many of these words originally seem to be military-derived, and back then, all the military were men.  The next one is the best of all.  Beyhive.  Well, I have no idea what bey is even supposed to mean these days.  I guess women have started referring to boyfriends as bey?  Well, bey is Turkish, and what did it mean?  Lord, as in title of honor in princely families. So, we'd be saying, "Hey, all you Lords!"  Hmmm, let's keep going.  Squad: small military unit (from the 1640's). Posse (late 13th century) means "body of men".  So, yes, Karen, there are implications to language and how we use it in society. commentThread.commentText: That‚Äôs what all this bullshit stems back to is the mis-defining or re-defining of words that have been in our language for decades. Only now some want to change our language to suit their purposes, interests and intentions ü§Æü§Æü§Æ

Wait until they find out about how the Spanish language works.  For those who don't know, unlike English, Spanish has masculine and feminine forms of the same word.  Typically the masculine form ends with the letter "o" and the feminine ends with the letter "a".  So referring to your friend who is a male would be "amigo", while a female would be "amiga".  The plural adds an "s" like English.  However, when referring to mixed company of males and females, the masculine form is used, "amigos".

When I was in college with roommates in which English was a second language, issues like this seemed to come up a lot in casual social interactions -- where they would ask me why phrases like "Hey guys!" was an issue. I explained it as thus to them: certain subsets of the population in the USA view many words and phrases in same way that swear words are used -- in that they generally can only be used in an offensive way (so we have made less offensive substitutes for those words when they are needed). It is unfortunate that they have extended so far now because these perceptions, as explored in this video, honestly discourage the inclusivity that the far left (to my understanding) is trying to promote -- and probably lessen the ability for those following this philosophy to reach out and learn more about other cultures and have constructive discussions between cultural & personal differences between all of us. The journey to find the speech to not offend anyone might end up being the journey for everyone to eventually lack a coherent opinion about anything. Thanks for the awesome videos.

I was a waiter once, chain restaurant. Tex-Mex cuisine. 
Not exactly a high dollar dining experience, large portions made consistantly mediocre, very quickly, for very cheap. 
It's a "4 top". Two women (I assume mother and daughter) and two teenage boys (I assume brothers borne of the daughter).
I said "Hey Guys, what can I get you to drink besides these waters?" We automatically brought tortilla chips, salsa and water to every table but I digress.
Grandma dips into a low growl by telling me "Don't you call us 'guys' again". The rest of the table is immediately uncomfortable so I apologized with "I'm sorry if you don't like the way I speak, I mean no offense; would you like to order or do you need a little more time?".
They didn't need more time. I took their entire order, put it in and brought out their drink order. When I got to the table I served the drinks ladies first in a circle and then the boys finishing with the oldest son while asking "can I get you guys anything else?".
Grandma goes guano. She tells me I should watch how I speak and how she will get me fired because she knows the owner. She was not to be called a "guy" because she didn't like it. She wanted to see a manager. 
I told her "I will gladly get the manager for you but I will never curtail my speech in my country....that I went to war for." 
Grandma didn't like that but I didn't lose that shit job over her. She got a free dessert.

The source of all this is lesbian feminism movement , which at the time wanted to demonise men and make all women lesbians. Its the hate that those lesbians (and not all lesbians) held for men, society and themselfs.

"On May 1, 1970, lesbianism became a serious issue at the ‚ÄúSecond Congress to Unite Women,‚Äù when lesbian activists such as The Radicalesbians chose this conference to educate feminists regarding the political obstacles faced by lesbians. At this event, the ‚ÄúLavender Menace‚Äù attempted to rush the stage to present lesbian issues and distributed copies of ‚ÄúThe Woman Identified Woman.‚Äù Although the lights were doused before the stage was rushed, this action led to pro-lesbian resolutions being passed at the conference‚Äôs final assembly. In 1971, the Radicalesbians disbanded.

At this time, many heterosexual feminists expressed discomfort over having sex re-injected into their feminist world, a world they believed to be outside of the androcentric relationships of sexuality. Echols argues that ‚Äú...the introduction of sex troubled many heterosexual feminists who had found in the women‚Äôs movement a welcome respite from sexuality.‚Äù Perhaps in response to heterosexual discomfort, lesbian feminists distanced themselves from the sexual aspect of lesbianism and assured feminists that lesbianism involved ‚Äúsensuality‚Äù not sexuality. Thus, Radicalesbians had to persuade feminists that lesbianism was not simply a bedroom issue, and that lesbians were not ‚Äúmale-identified ‚Äòbogeywomen‚Äô out to sexually exploit women‚Äù (Echols, 216).

In essence, lesbian feminists tried to untie lesbianism from sex so heterosexual feminists were more comfortable. But they still had to find an effective way to address the accusation that their masculinity was somehow complicit with men and patriarchy. Lesbian feminists responded by distancing themselves from stereotypes of ‚Äúmasculine roles,‚Äù maleness, and patriarchy. One way they were able to do so was by disentangling lesbian sexuality from heterosexuality and re-conceptualizing heterosexual sex as consorting with ‚Äúthe enemy‚Äù. They capitalized on dominant assumptions regarding female sexuality, including ideas of women‚Äôs romantic and nurturing sexuality versus men‚Äôs aggressive sexuality. They were then able to draw a distinction between lesbian sex and heterosexual sex, claiming that lesbian sex was ‚Äúpure as snow‚Äù since it did not involve men. For example, ‚Äú‚Ä¶the male seeks to conquer through sex while the female seeks to communicate‚Äù and ‚Äú‚Ä¶lesbians are obsessed with love and fidelity‚Äù (Echols, 218).

Using this ideology, lesbians successfully billed lesbianism as an ultimate form of feminism--a practice that did not involve men on any emotional level. In this way, heterosexual feminists were seen as inferior because of their continued association with men. Lesbians took on a ‚Äúvanguard‚Äù quality as the ‚Äútrue‚Äù bearers of feminism. As radical feminism became more associated with lesbianism, heterosexual feminists left the movement.

Within the feminist movement, lesbian feminists were often accused of elitism and arrogance, because they considered themselves the ‚Äúvanguard‚Äù of feminism. As a result of the differences between Radicalesbians and feminists, Rita Mae Brown and approximately 9 other women formed a lesbian separatist group called ‚ÄúThe Furies Collective.‚Äù The Furies became famous for their newsletter of the same name. Unlike the Radicalesbians, The Furies were not as successful in jump-starting a large-scale separatist movement - but they did ‚Äúset the terms of the debate‚Äù (Echols, 228). "

replies.commentText:
‚Äã@LemonZeppelin Don't forget that it is offensive to the nap and siesta community, as they wake up multiple times a day.
Furthermore it is also offensive to late awaken community, which woke up too late for it to be considered morning.
It is also extremely offensive to the vampire, werewolf and other night creature communities (humanoid or not, fictional or not), since they wake up at night. However saying "Good night!" is also offensive as the societal construct around the phrase would suggest that they were going to sleep, rather than just waking up.
I suggest using the phrase "Have a pleasant awakening!" to include those people. Some might argue that werewolves were already awake before transforming, but that is irrelevant, since you aren't saying it to the human part of the werewolf, but rather the wolf part of it that has at the time assumed control over the body.'
And lastly it can offend the pessimistic, nihilistic, dystopianist and other similar communities, as they expect or even want a bad morning to occur, rather than a good one.
As such, a universal non-offensive phrase "You have awaken, congrats!" is suggested, as that doesn't assume how the rest of the day is gonna go, but rather assumes that you have awoken, which is necessary for the phrase to be in use. Some have argued that the people who can't wake up may find it offensive, but we have yet to hear any complaints from them.
